videos.description: Thomas gives an Introduction to Hardware! Learn about things like side channels, fault injection, and much more. Generally, when people think of cybersecurity, they don't consider the hardware aspect of it. This is a unique opportunity to learn about a side of security that you might not have thought of before.
videos.speaker: Thomas Garcia
videos.title: Intro to Hardware

videos.description: Preventing unauthorized access to any network is critical. If a malicious user were to gain access to a corporation's network, they could steal information like credit card numbers, social security numbers, and so much more. Join us as Kylan discusses different aspects of network security!
videos.speaker: Kylan Stewart
videos.title: Network Security

videos.description: What's better than a Pumpkin Spice Latte on a breezy fall day? Some sick vulns, that's what! Join us for our doubleheader talk as Nicole and Kylan discuss the Dirty COW and Foreshadow vulnerabilities. Dirty COW has existed since 2007 but was just fixed in 2016 and Foreshadow was discovered earlier this year, so both are very topical issues.
videos.speaker: Nicole Anderson-Au and Kylan Stewart
videos.title: Dirty COW and Foreshadow

videos.description: Cryptography is one of the most important tools for building a secure system, and it has a wide variety of uses in security. However, if used incorrectly, the results can be disastrous. White Hat Vice President, Nicole, gives an introduction to this extremely important and fascinating subject.
videos.speaker: Nicole Anderson-Au
videos.title: Intro to Cryptography

videos.description: What goes into catching hackers in video games? Austin discusses various forms of anticheat and anticracking software, as well as the privacy implications of such programs. Learn about how companies are hurt by pirates and cheaters, and the measures developers have taken to protect their intellectual property.
videos.speaker: Austin Shin
videos.title: Video Game Security

videos.description: At the core of everything you do on your computer is the operating system: the command center that keeps every program in its place. With the OS having such a monumental job, security should be a critical part of its development. Join alumni officer Nick Gonella in learning just how this insane piece of software works (or more often, how it fails to work).
videos.speaker: Nick Gonella
videos.title: Intro to OS

videos.description: Jon discusses virtual machines. Virtual machines have many benefits from a security and privacy standpoint, as they are isolated from their host system, are easy to backup/restore, and do not allow fingerprinting of the host OS.
videos.speaker: Jon Prentice
videos.title: Virtual Machines

videos.description: Sarah discusses our relationship with data and the incentives that companies have to use it.
videos.speaker: Sarah Samora
videos.title: Intro to Privacy

videos.description:
Ethan Goldfarb - History of Computer Security
Justin Engwall - Weaponizing Cyber
Austin Shin - Anti-Cheat Software
Veronica Pollock - Password Security
Kylan Stewart - What is White Hat?
videos.speaker: White Hat
videos.title: Lightning Talks

videos.description: Nate discusses Ethernet works, from copper wires to sending frames. Learn how we actually shove gigabits through unshielded cables reliably enough to watch cat videos!
videos.speaker: Nate Graff
videos.title: Ethernet

videos.description: Marina discusses the onion router. Learn about TOR, how it works, and how to use it!
videos.speaker: Marina Moore
videos.title: TOR

videos.description: Kylan discusses the wonderful world of sponge functions! These are really fascinating and are something we may see more discussion about in upcoming cryptography.
videos.speaker: Kylan Stewart
videos.title: Hashes and the Crypto Sponge

videos.description: Marina talks about the GDPR. She discusses the EU General Data Protection Regulation, which goes into effect later this year, as well as the implications it may have. This will be a great talk about privacy, which is a very important part of all our lives on the internet.
videos.speaker: Marina Moore
videos.title: GDPR (General Data Protection Regulation)

videos.description:
Nathan Lemay gives an advanced talk about hacking security's weakest link - humans. He talks about the tools and technologies needed to launch a successful campaign. Learn all about the usefulness and necessity for social engineering as a tool in security assessments!

[From May 2017]
videos.speaker: Nathan Lemay
videos.title: Social Engineering

videos.description: Max Zinkus, White Hat President, talks about Cryptocurrencies! He discusses Trust, Verification, and Privacy--how we establish trust on the internet with and without prior knowledge. Additionally, he covers proof of knowledge systems critical to blockchains, and other cryptographic primitives which can be used to achieve privacy and trust over the internet.
videos.speaker: Max Zinkus
videos.title: Cryptocurrencies (Trust, Verification, and Privacy)

videos.description: Nate's talk on Real Time Operating Systems! He discusses what a real time operating system is, why we need them, and how we can use them to build responsive, resilient systems.
videos.speaker: Nate Graff
videos.title: Real Time Operating Systems (RTOS)

videos.description: Johnathan Nicholson talks about kernel security. General kernel security as well as some basic information about modules, dirty COW, and access control.
videos.speaker: Johnathan Nicholson
videos.title: Kernel Security

videos.description:
Max Zinkus - What is White Hat
Nick Gonella - So You Want To Do Security
Marina Moore - Definition of Hacker
Nate Graff - Hardware Security
Kylan Stewart - Lockpicking
Jasper Kahn - CTFs in a Flash
videos.speaker: White Hat
videos.title: Lightning Talks

videos.description: Abineet talks about Ransomware and some of the infamous attacks that occurred in 2017, including WannaCry. With an explosion in the popularity of crypto-currencies, these type of attacks will be much more prevalent, especially in emerging platforms of Autonomous Vehicles and IoT devices.
videos.speaker: Abineet Singh
videos.title: Ransomware

videos.description: Learn what TLS is, how it works, and how and why we use it.
videos.speaker: Nick Frost
videos.title: TLS

videos.description: Have you ever wondered what runs your computer? Do you want to know what this whole "ssh [username@]host" thing is all about? Well, this talk is for you! Learn about the cool OS - UNIX! White Hat Corporate Liaison presents about the history of UNIX, OSes, and some tools you should know!
videos.speaker: Marina Moore
videos.title: Intro to UNIX

videos.description:
Have you ever wondered if the data you post privately stays that way? Can companies sell your pictures or make them into their own ads? Maybe you intently read privacy policies instead of just clicking accept on the terms and conditions.
White Hat Publicist Kylan Stewart presents about these topics and more in the realm of privacy.
videos.speaker: Kylan Stewart
videos.title: Intro to Privacy

videos.description: White Hat President, Max Zinkus explores how to use javascript to exploit target computers through browsers. Learn how browsers try to protect themselves and how those protections can be defeated.
videos.speaker: Max Zinkus
videos.title: Browser Exploitation

videos.description: White Hat Officer Nick Gonella's explores the strengths and limitations of applied homomorphic encryption, a topic in cryptography that is still largely theoretical. Nick shows how RSA works and uncovers a critical pitfall in RSA that homomorphic encryption aims to solve. Nick explains these models with respect to the Confidentiality-Integrity-Availability (CIA) Triad.
videos.speaker: Nick Gonella
videos.title: Homomorphic Encryption

videos.description: White Hat Officer Nate Graff presents the authentication standards surrounding the hardware chips that we use in our daily routines: credit cards, sim cards, Apple Pay, etc.
videos.speaker: Nate Graff
videos.title: Hardware Authentication Tokens

videos.description: What is fuzzing? How do the genetic algorithms work? White Hat Officer Max Zinkus dives into these two pressing topics. Demos are included!
videos.speaker: Max Zinkus
videos.title: Fuzzing

videos.description:
White Hat Officer Amy Tsai is talking about SQL injection attacks! Watch this video to learn several techniques to defend against users, whether you're using SQL or another database system. 
Try it out with these sites on our lab wifi (not campus wifi)!

Resources: 
crackme.cenzic.com (PHP app)
hackthissite.org
testasp.vulnweb.com (IIS, ASP.NET, Microsoft SQL Server); also Acunetix
https://google-gruyere.appspot.com/
Google Gruyere, a web-application meant to be attacked, hosted by Google.
videos.speaker: Amy Tsai
videos.title: SQL Injection

videos.description:
How can a messaging app be engineered to protect privacy? Dylan Howell shows us how different messaging protocols handle privacy. Find out which app is best for your needs and how each compares.

Signal for iOS: https://itunes.apple.com/us/app/signal-private-messenger/id874139669?mt=8

Signal for Android: https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=org.thoughtcrime.securesms&hl=en
videos.speaker: Dylan Howell
videos.title: Crypto Messaging Protocols

videos.description:
Come learn why torrenting was invented, what communities are out there, and how these networks work. Is torrenting bad? White Hat Officer Nick Frost explains the practical benefits of torrenting and shows us industry uses of this peer to peer design. Nick also warns that torrent networks don't conform to the critical foundations of encryption.

Beware: Torrenting is not allowed on the campus wifi.
videos.speaker: Nick Frost
videos.title: Peer-to-Peer Networks

videos.description:
Shahid Buttar, the director of Grassroots Advocacy from the Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF), advocates for privacy. Get ready for a nerve-wracking political and cultural history of privacy and surveillance in the United States legal system. 
Links:
https://www.eff.org/
https://www.eff.org/about/staff/shahid-buttar
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eisenhower's_farewell_address
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Legacy_of_Ashes_(book)
videos.speaker: Electronic Frontier Foundation
videos.title: Shahid Buttar

videos.description:
Should we be concerned about applications and sites that expose our metadata? Why does fingerprinting matter? 

White Hat Officer Marina Moore is talking about various aspects of privacy in the digital world. Marina introduces points to consider as a user and as a servicer. Enjoy the talk and join the discussion about privacy.
videos.speaker: Marina Moore
videos.title: Intro to Privacy

videos.description: Electrical and Computer Engineers, this video is for you! White Hat Officer Nate Graff introduces various fields of security that require hardware engineering. Nate also talks some wild hardware exploits and the recent event attributed to the infectious Internet of Things.
videos.speaker: Nate Graff
videos.title: Intro to Hardware Security

videos.description: White Hat Officer Nick Gonella talks about the history behind UNIX systems and how UNIX was the precursor to most modern operating systems. Don't let UNIX be turtles to you! Watch the video to learn about the structure and design of UNIX.
videos.speaker: Nick Gonella
videos.title: Intro to UNIX

videos.description:
White Hat Officer Amy Tsai is talking about social engineering!

Amy describes the scale of this issue in industry, and various techniques employed by such crafty adversaries. Don't be vulnerable. Learn the nature of these attacks and be ready recognize a situation where you and your organization may need further protection.

Keep your white hats on!
We encourage you to familiarize yourself with security hazards. That being said, we do not encourage social engineering or assume responsibility for anyone who engages in social engineering.
videos.speaker: Amy Tsai
videos.title: Social Engineering

videos.description:
Yuan Tian, is pursuing a Ph.D. from Cylab, Carnegie Mellon University. 

In this talk, Yuan Tian explains the design of Android Security. Yuan then follows with a discussion about why Android is vulnerable to so many attacks.

So how can we protect ourselves from malicious apps? Are there malware detection tools? Yuan Tian introduces APKInspector, a tool she has developed for malware analysis on Android!

Links: 
http://www.mysmu.edu/phdis2012/yuan.tian.2012/default.htm
http://code.google.com/p/androguard/
videos.speaker: Yuan Tian
videos.title: Android Security

videos.description:
Puzzles and Crypto -- Marina Moore
Hardware Security -- Nate Graff
Operational Security -- Max Zinkus
Security Fails -- Jasper Kahn
videos.speaker: White Hat Officers
videos.title: Security Lightning Talks

videos.description:
Drew Miller, White Hat's former CTF Master, explains the four phases needed to manipulate traffic with a Pineapple Wifi. Drew shows how the Pineapple Wifi provides connection reports and a lot of neat modules to tinker with; Drew's favorites are SSLsplit, DWall, and RandomRoll. What are yours?

This video also touches on the differences and similarities between Tetra and the Nano and Dr. DeBruhl's Intro to Network Security Course.
videos.speaker: Drew Miller
videos.title: Pineapple Wifi

videos.description:
White Hat CTF Master Nick Gonella gives a high-level mathematical look at Quantum Cryptography. Nick starts with the idea of using Asymmetric Encryption to solve the codebook problem of Symmetric Encryption. Nick also dives into Quantum concepts like superposition of states, duality, and the issues that RSA presents when confronted with Shor's algorithm and techniques from Number Theory. Watch Nick's talk to see how the mathematics surrounding this topic surpasses the computational capabilities of current computers.

What is Elliptic Curve Cryptography? See Nick's talk on ECC: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FyrNkMDL120
videos.speaker: Nick Gonella
videos.title: Destroy All Crypto

videos.description:
Both Android and iOS are based on UNIX. Assistant CTF Master Jasper Kahn talks about how this has affected the history of Mobile Security, along with third party app stores, XCode, iKee, YiSpecter, the CoreText bug, and Stagefright 2.0. Listen in to hear a few legality caveats surrounding the topic of rooting your tablets and phones. 
Thank you to the Cal Poly Mobile App Development Club for this joint meeting on Mobile Security with White Hat!

Cal Poly Mobile App Dev Club: http://polyappdev.club/index.html
videos.speaker: Jasper Kahn
videos.title: Mobile Security

videos.description:
Bill Britton is the Interim Chief Information Officer (CIO) and Director of the Cybersecurity Center at Cal Poly. Britton says it's time for cybersecurity to work together with information technology.

The California Cyber Training Complex (CCTC) at Camp SLO has growing plans to set up Forensics Field Training programs in law enforcement alongside cybersecurity research projects. Camp SLO's Field Training is entirely unique and students are going to be a key component of the program during the year! 

Britton explains that the biggest challenges for law enforcement are in the field of forensics. There will also be a Case Study Library program for engineering students and non-engineering students to work together and publish cybersecurity papers. The idea is to help law enforcement and other non-engineering audiences understand these issues. Britton also envisions hosting educational youth camps in the summer months and sponsoring the Cyber Patriot program.
videos.speaker: Bill Britton, Director of Cal Poly's Cybersecurity Center and CIO
videos.title: Camp SLO

videos.description:
Are your locks easy to pick? White Hat member Nate Graff demonstrates lockpicking and shows the mechanics of common locks through animations!

Links:

Combination Counter
http://www.lockcodes.com/combcoun/

(728) Rappin' on Masterlock -- bosnianbill 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pU9MB5XPsp4&t=15

Overlifting -- Schuyler Towne
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jaPFOcHpRNM

TOOOL 
http://toool.us/

DEF CON
https://www.defcon.org/
videos.speaker: Nate Graff
videos.title: Intro to Lock Security

videos.description: Do you really understand RC4? Want to see how a block cipher decryption works? White Hat Advisor Dr. Zachary Peterson talks about a few major crypto fails. He includes a Key-stream distribution of RC4's outputs, describes a cross-protocol attack, and explains the Heartbleed bug in OpenSSL.
videos.speaker: Dr. Zachary Peterson
videos.title: Big Crypto Fails

videos.description:
Dr. Fred Cohen is the President of the Pebble Beach Chapter of the Keiretsu Forum Northern California Region. He discusses the fundamentals of business development and how can changes in information technology can result in changes in business. Do security breaches matter or do the consequences of security breaches matter? How can you balance access controls and availability?

Dr. Cohen also recounts stories from the recent RSA Conference in San Francisco. 

Dr. Cohen's Model: http://all.net/Arch/index.html
Dr. Cohen's bio: http://all.net/resume/bio.html
videos.speaker: Fred Cohen
videos.title: Fred Cohen

videos.description:
Nick Kartsioukas describes the different types of wifi, what makes them secure, and where their vulnerabilities lie. 

Do you want to know the whether to use WEP, WPA, or WPA2? Are you considering setting up your own Certificate Authority? Enjoy the video!

Twitter: @explodinglemur  
github.com/explodinglemur/presentations

Recommendations: 

http://etutorials.org/Networking/802....

802.11, 802.1x, and Wireless Security
https://www.sans.org/reading-room/whi...

Hacking 802.11 Basics: 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zxs0s...

Wireless Pentesting:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kMq7u...

Aircrack-ng Tutorials: 
http://www.aircrack-ng.org/doku.php?i...
videos.speaker: Nick Kartsioukas
videos.title: Wifi Security

videos.description:
White Hat Officer Max Zinkus sheds light on the common types of Virtualization, a means of abstraction to share your system hardware between various softwares. Learn about the strengths and threats of virtualization and see a visual explanation of the strategy used by Amazon Web Services (AWS). Also listen to the Q&A to hear about the tradeoff behind AWS's decision to forbid copy-on-writes.  

Want to know more? Max recommends looking into the mechanics of known vulnerabilities through wikis and white papers. 

The Invisible Things Lab Blog: http://blog.invisiblethings.org/
videos.speaker: Max Zinkus
videos.title: Virtualization

videos.description:
Have you ever wondered if your phone calls and text messages are being subjected to man-in-the-middle (MITM) attacks? How old is this bug and why is it still alive? White Hat alum Maria Pikusova tells us about International Mobile Subscriber Identity (IMSI) Catchers, tools that take advantage of the Global System for Mobile Communcations' (GSM) authentication bug to intercept your cell phone communications, for better or for worse. 

Whether or not this worries you, you should watch this video! Pikusova also shows us an open sourced app that is written to detect IMSI Catchers. Check out the app, investigate the laws about IMSI Catchers in your county, and share what you find in a comment.
videos.speaker: Maria Pikusova
videos.title: IMSI Catchers

videos.description:
White Hat member Johnathan Nicholson shows us how to crack passwords with a live demo. Nicholson explains how passwords are stored, the various ways to uncover them, and why you'll need a GPU.  

Watch this video to understand why some passwords are more secure than others and to hear the discussion regarding this "grey hat" pursuit.
videos.speaker: Johnathan Nicholson
videos.title: Cracking Passwords With a GPU

videos.description:
White Hat member Ryan Gelston is shedding light on Artificial Intelligence (AI). Just how far into the future is AI? Are there any computer programs in today's existence that can recursively improve themselves? Will computers ever develop empathy? If you're curious about the discussions surrounding AI or you just like dank memes, watch this video. 

Gelston also describes John Searle's Chinese Room thought experiment and what happened to the Horse ebooks AI.
videos.speaker: Ryan Gelston
videos.title: AI Security

videos.description:
"What is the block chain and what does "mining for Bitcoin" really mean" you ask? Watch this video. White Hat Treasurer Nick Gonella explains how Bitcoin transactions work. 

Nick also covers concepts like wallet automation, Merkle trees, hashes, the Silk Road and the variety of reasons that lead people to use Bitcoin.
videos.speaker: Nick Gonella
videos.title: Cryptocurrency

videos.description: Dr. Bruce DeBruhl researches and teaches cyber-physical security, network security, and web security. Dr. DeBruhl talks about the cyber-physical system model and its properties. Why do we need to secure these systems? Watch this talk to learn about previous cyber-physical attacks and modern contexts of cyber-physical security.
videos.speaker: Dr. Bruce DeBruhl
videos.title: Cyber-Physical Security

videos.description:
White Hat CTF Master Drew Miller goes into detail about Virtual Capture the Flag (CTF) and invites us to participate in upcoming Attack/Defense style challenges in the Security Lab to exploit vulnerabilities as a team.

Example urls
https://github.com/pcchou/ctf-writeups/tree/master/tum-ctf-teaser-2015/neocities

Resources to Prepare
http://overthewire.org/wargames
https://www.hackthissite.org
https://picoctf.com  
https://ctftime.org/writeups -- Find out how others solved specific challenges.

Upcoming CTFs
https://ctftime.org -- See a complete CTF calendar here, including Jeopardy CTFs:

NSA Cybersprint
https://registration.cyberwargames.net/cybersprint
NSA.gov/Careers

RuCTF -- Nov 21, 2015 -- (TEAM) Attack Defense
https://ructf.org/index.en.html

UCSB iCTF  -- December 4, 2015 -- (TEAM) Attack Defense  
http://ictf.cs.ucsb.edu

Ghost in the Shellcode -- January 8/9, 2015  
http://ghostintheshellcode.com
videos.speaker: Drew Miller
videos.title: Intro to CTFs

videos.description:
Learn about Networks from White Hat Corporate Liaison Max Zinkus. Max goes through the TCP/IP model, the Open Systems Interconnection (OSI) Model, and important related concepts.

Curious about the differences between IPv4 and IPv6, TCP and UDP, or Distributed DOS and Reflection DOS? What is a NIC, NAT, an RFC, a DOS, or a DNS Request? Want to know more about Port Scanning? Max covers it all and he explains why Nmap and WireShark should not be done on campus wifi.

Try out White Hat hacking with us on our separate wifi in the White Hat Security Lab, Bonderson (197-204). 

See former White Hat President Cristina Formaini's talk on SSL/TLS: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Rp3iZUvXWlM
videos.speaker: Max Zinkus
videos.title: Networks

videos.description:
White Hat Treasurer Nick Gonella shows us the UNIX experience starting with the history of UNIX, what distinguishes the UNIX system structure, and discussing the philosophy of the system. Want to get started? Applicable demos in the shell/terminal are included within the context of the Over the Wire Bandit wargame. 

Bandit is a great resource designed for beginners. 
Experience unix: http://overthewire.org/wargames/bandit/

Join the Cal Poly Linux Users Group: http://cplug.org
videos.speaker: Nick Gonella
videos.title: Intro to UNIX

videos.description: White Hat officers explain what ethical hacking is what it means to be in White Hat. Tune in to learn about What Security Looks Like, Ciphers in the Media, Historical Codes and Ciphers, Social Engineering, Steganography, and Crypto Fails.
videos.speaker: White Hat Officers
videos.title: Security Fundamentals

videos.description:
Nick Gonella, officer of White Hat, talks about Elliptic Curve Cryptography (ECC), a cutting edge encryption method that is taking the cryptography world by storm. Learn the machinery behind this new technology and how it's being used today.

Recommended read on ECC: https://blog.cloudflare.com/a-relatively-easy-to-understand-primer-on-elliptic-curve-cryptography/
videos.speaker: Nick Gonella
videos.title: Elliptic Curve Cryptography (EEC)

videos.description: Your software may be secure, but what about the computer it's running on? Nathaniel Graff describes how private data can be extracted from a running system without even needing a software exploit. Learn how data can be inadvertently leaked and what can be done to prevent it. Featuring a live demo with an oscilloscope!
videos.speaker: Nathaniel Graff
videos.title: Side-Channel Attacks by Differential Power Analysis

videos.description: How does a text file turn into machine code? How can a compiler make your code faster? The new White Hat Vice President, Jared Shumway, presents how a compiler works, how it can be used to write better code, and how you can make it output obfuscated binaries! Learn about the internals of an optimizing compiler and some projects that can make your code more secure.
videos.speaker: Jared Shumway
videos.title: Compilers

videos.description:
Luis Cuéllar introduces penetration testing, why it is important, and some resources available. Cuéllar also gives a demonstration of common vulnerabilities within web servers and shows you how to attack your own PHP web server, encode executable scripts, and gain root access.

Recommended Resources:

Securityfocus.com/bid
Overthewire.org
Hackthissite.org
Wechall.net
CTFs
videos.speaker: Luis Cuéllar
videos.title: Penetration Testing

videos.description:
What is TLS and how is it different from SSL? What is Firesheep? How can you sniff your own traffic on Wireshark?  

Cristina Formaini, president of White Hat, Cal Poly talks about ensuring confidentiality, integrity, and authenticity to secure communications over a network. This video explains Certificates of Authority (CA), public and private keys, the recent POODLE Attack of October 2014, and the common exploits of SSL. 

More Information:

Poodle Fix: https://www.openssl.org/~bodo/ssl-poodle.pdf

https://www.imperialviolet.org/2014/10/14/poodle.html

Padding Oracle Attack: http://robertheaton.com/2013/07/29/padding-oracle-attack/

Black Hat 2011 - Future of SSL and Authenticity: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Z7Wl2FW2TcA
videos.speaker: Cristina Formaini
videos.title: SSL/TLS

videos.description: How can we secure data? What does data security mean? Peter Faiman, White Hat VP, will talk about data security and the cryptographic tools used to secure data, including pseudo-random functions (PRFs), cryptographic hashes, message authentication codes (MACs), and encryption algorithms.
videos.speaker: Peter Faiman
videos.title: Secure Storage

videos.description: The goals of Cal Poly’s cyber initiative—which includes hardware and software, facilities, and curriculum development—are to produce qualified graduates in computer science with a cybersecurity specialization as well as to educate them in advanced engineering, science, and business applications of cyber technologies and systems. The initiative is also aimed at preparing students for service in support of the national defense industry and intelligence community as well as for advanced study and applied research.
videos.speaker: Bill Britton
videos.title: Cybersecurity Initiative

videos.description: Peter Faiman White Hat VP, talks about pseudo-random number generators (PRNGs), random number quality, and the importance of unpredictable random numbers to cryptography.
videos.speaker: Peter Faiman
videos.title: Pseudo Random Number Generators

videos.description:
User input validation is the area of computer science most easily analogized to a redneck bunker in the middle of the desert: full of a seemingly unnecessary amount of heavy weaponry, and a severe mistrust of anything that moves.

When people make programs, they often have an intuition that the user will interact with the program in a particular way. That would be a wonderful, wonderful thing, except THE USER IS EVIL. Whether through outright malice or staggering incompetence, the user will do something completely horribly wrong that will break your application if you don't prepare for it.

In this talk, Peter Faiman (White Hat VP) will be covering the most common types of user input, the problems to avoid with this input, and how to have the proper mindset for dealing with the vicious zombie army, your users.
videos.speaker: Peter Faiman
videos.title: Input Sanitization

videos.description: Jared, White Hat Treasurer, will be giving a talk on software tools! The quickest route to becoming a better software engineer is to start using software to build (or break) software. From simple unix utilities and make to entire suites of custom tooling, come learn about the stages of tools expertise and how to create better software, faster.
videos.speaker: Jared Shumway
videos.title: Tools

videos.description: Jessie, former White Hat president, will be giving a talk on firewalls! During this introduction to firewalls talk, we will be exploring the history, theory, and practical uses of firewalls. The talk will explore both strengths, limitations, and implementations. At the end we will do a couple hands on activities, so bring your computer if you want to participate. This talk is aimed to give an intro to firewalls for beginners, and excite the experienced.
videos.speaker: Jessie Pease
videos.title: Firewalls

videos.description: Jared, White Hat Treasurer, will be presenting on session hijacking! Broken authentication and session management is the second most common vulnerability on the OWASP top 10 list. Mishandling session tokens can allow adversaries to silently take over another user's account while circumventing the authentication system. Let's talk about why HTTPS is so important, why Fire Sheep was awesome, how session hijacking is possible, and how to implement secure session handling and what trade offs are involved.
videos.speaker: Jared Shumway
videos.title: Session Hijacking

videos.description: Corey will be talking about Git and the underlying concepts of its design. Even if you're already experienced with using Git for version control, understanding these concepts can help make you a more productive software developer.
videos.speaker: Corey Ford
videos.title: Understanding Git

videos.description: Jared, White Hat Treasurer, will be discussing Heartbleed; disclosed in April 2014, Heartbleed, a bug in the OpenSSL heartbeat extension left major sites vulnerable. By exploiting a memory error, attackers could dump entire sections of an OpenSSL process's memory leaking everything from SSL certificates to user authentication credentials.
videos.speaker: Jared Shumway
videos.title: Heartbleed

videos.description: Maggie, White Hat Events Coordinator, will be giving a talk about the first worm with physical results, Stuxnet. This is the first in a series of in depth looks at the major hacks in computing.
videos.speaker: Maggie Duffy
videos.title: Stuxnet

videos.description: In 2014, there were over 1 billion Android devices shipped, the most of any mobile OS ever. Using some hand-wavy statistics, this equates to one device running Android for every seven people on Earth. This means that Android is a very lucrative target for hackers, as the potential gain from an exploit is very large. Come join White Hat officer Andrew Kennedy and learn about what measures Google has taken to minimize the attack vectors on the world's most popular mobile OS.
videos.speaker: Andrew Kennedy
videos.title: Android Security

videos.description: Strong cryptography is an important tool for keeping your information private from companies, governments and others. Come learn about cryptographic tools to protect your communications, including PGP encryption for email, and some of the underlying mathematical magic.
videos.speaker: Corey Ford and Liam Kirsh
videos.title: PGP

videos.description: Peter, White Hat VP, will be giving a talk about classic hacks, some of which pre-date the internet. Several old school hacks are notorious for causing tremendous monetary damage or media sensation, and some are just particularly awesome or culturally relevant.
videos.speaker: Peter Faiman
videos.title: Old School Hacking

videos.description: Cristina and Peter, respective President & Vice President of White Hat, will be giving an introductory talk on networks and network security!
videos.speaker: Cristina Formaini and Peter Faiman
videos.title: Networks

videos.description: Peter, White Hat VP, will be teaching the basics of the UNIX core system that underlies Linux and Mac OS X. We'll be building on many of the things learned in Over the Wire and PicoCTF with an emphasis on explaining the how and why, and the UNIX philosophy.
videos.speaker: Peter Faiman
videos.title: Intro To Unix

videos.description:
While solutions for file system encryption can prevent an adversary from determining the contents of files, in situations where a user wishes to hide the existence of data, encryption alone is not sufficient. Indeed, encryption may draw attention to those files, as they may likely contain information the user wishes to keep secret; adversarial coercion may motivate the owner to surrender their encryption keys, under duress.

In this talk, Prof. Peterson will discuss recent research results in creating a deniable, encrypted file system designed to work within the technical constraints imposed by solid-state drives, such as those found in mobile devices. This system provides features not offered by prior work, including: authenticated encryption, fast secure deletion, support for multiple layers of deniability, and security against the strongest adversary considered in this setting.
videos.speaker: Dr. Peterson
videos.title: DEFY (Deniable Encrypted File System from YAFFS)
